paragraphs.text: Secret spice-shopping tip (which also works for sesame seeds): see if your grocery store carries spices in the “Ethnic Foods” aisle. For some reason, spices are like 1/10 the price there.

9520a1f97527.title: The typical loaf sticking out of the bag may indeed be a baguette, but in general the easiest way…

content.subtitle: Here’s a picture of what I would call baguettes, for reference:

virtuals.subtitle: Here’s a picture of what I would call baguettes, for reference:

paragraphs.text: The typical loaf sticking out of the bag may indeed be a baguette, but in general the easiest way to identify a baguette is by its shape/size. The word “baguette” roughly translates as “wand,” “rod” or “stick.” This the traditional French baguette tends to be more narrow than the one in the photo. The French bread in the photo would more likely just…
paragraphs.name: 213d

80c1cb9d73a8.title: If you want to cook the chicken in the slow cooker, cook the chicken in the slow cooker.

paragraphs.text: If you want to cook the chicken in the slow cooker, cook the chicken in the slow cooker. I do not think that this meal plan is some scientifically or spiritually optimized plan. It’s a nice, common sense meal plan, but it’s not the magical thing that is going to make your life complete. It’s not THE SECRET!

ebe13468f18f.title: That is super expensive for steel cut oats.

paragraphs.text: That is super expensive for steel cut oats. Is that the only brand your grocery store had? Trader Joe’s and Whole Foods both have house brands that are much less expensive. Sesame seeds can be purchased for half the price at any proper spice or “ethnic” store, or even at TJ’s. And this is coming from someone in New York!

8bdcf8354a4b.title: Consider finding your local Big Lots.

paragraphs.text: Consider finding your local Big Lots. They carry Bob’s Red Mill brand and the steel cut oats would be much less costly there. They also often get herbs and other pantry staples that are discounted over a grocery store price. Not everything is a great price, but if you know your costs normally, you can see which ones are cheaper. Baked snack foods…

7a8fc7a1d63d.title: I will say, the big advantage of steel-cut oats is that you can make a big pot at the beginning of…

paragraphs.text: I will say, the big advantage of steel-cut oats is that you can make a big pot at the beginning of the week and they can be reheated later, which just doesn’t work with rolled oats — they get all rubbery and gross if you reheat them. Plus, they lend themselves to overnight slow-cooker magic, so you can have breakfast for the whole week ready when you wake up Monday morning.
paragraphs.name: 0dd9

paragraphs.text: For example, checking instacart for Whole Foods prices near you, a 2.08 oz jar is $3.69, but the bulk is $5.99 a pound. That’s fully 5 times as expensive.
I’d be interested in what the exact same thing would have cost at Whole Foods …

84c35303eeb.title: Breadsplaining but not trying to sound snooty: A baguette is a specific type of bread, per width…

paragraphs.text: Breadsplaining but not trying to sound snooty: A baguette is a specific type of bread, per width and length. It has a crisp crust and lots of air pockets. From your photo, it looks like your bread is sort of “imitation baguette,” i.e. what is called in the U.S. Italian or French bread. Again, I can only base this on the picture, but I am assuming it does not have a super crisp crust nor many air pockets within.

b6b974a62535.title: Steel cut oats really are a lot better than rolled.

content.subtitle: Unless you or someone you’re serving has celiac disease. Oats aren’t *supposed* to produce gluten, but they can pick up DNA from non-oat…

virtuals.subtitle: Unless you or someone you’re serving has celiac disease. Oats aren’t *supposed* to produce gluten, but they can pick up DNA from non-oat…

paragraphs.text: Steel cut oats really are a lot better than rolled. They can be found for much more reasonable prices somewhere that sells bulk dry goods that you scoop out of bins. I’ve had success at spice shops and “ethnic” grocers in the past.
paragraphs.name: ff81

paragraphs.text: Steel cut oats really are a lot better than rolled. They can be found for much more reasonable prices somewhere that sells bulk dry goods that you scoop out of bins. I’ve had success at spice shops and “ethnic” grocers in the past.
paragraphs.name: ff81

paragraphs.text: I should also note that a tiny thing of sesame seeds costs $5.69, which is ridiculous, and those steel-cut oats cost $8.99, which is super ridiculous. Those two items took up 20 percent of my grocery bill.
